cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 170, Number 76 (Thursday, May 2, 2024)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. LAWLER:H.R. 8231.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, clause 7The single subject of this legislation is:To award a congressional gold medal to James Earl Jones, anAmerican icon, in recognition of a remarkable life inreshaping perceptions, dismantling racial barriers, andadvocating for equal opportunities for people of allbackgrounds in film and theatre.[Page H2835]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

item.fullName: Del. Sablan, Gregorio Kilili Camacho [D-MP-At Large]

bill.title: James Earl Jones Congressional Gold Medal Act

item.title: James Earl Jones Congressional Gold Medal Act
James Earl Jones Congressional Gold Medal Act

To award a congressional gold medal to James Earl Jones, an American icon, in recognition of a remarkable life in reshaping perceptions, dismantling racial barriers, and advocating for equal opportunities for people of all backgrounds in film and theatre.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
